explanation: metal_virt2phys: The for-loop body calls metal_virt2phys(virt + offset, &phys[page]). To check MISRA's requirements about side effects and objects modified by the loop body you must know the function prototype and its full semantics: which objects it may modify (global state, memory reachable from its first argument, the phys array, or any object reachable via globals), whether it can modify the loop counter (page) or the loop condition variable (pages) indirectly, and whether it has any persistent side effects that would make the second clause invalid. METAL_BAD_OFFSET: This symbol is assigned inside the loop on error. You must confirm it is an object-like constant (no side effects) and not a macro or function that could have persistent side effects or modify other objects used in the loop. metal_phys_addr_t: The type of elements in phys[] (and the type expected by metal_virt2phys). Knowing its definition is needed to determine whether writes through &phys[page] can alias or otherwise affect objects used in the for-clause (e.g. if it is a complex type with side-effecting assignment operators in some environment). struct metal_page_size: The loop uses pages computed from ps->page_size and uses ps elsewhere. You need the definition to confirm page_size type/semantics (and whether accessing ps or its fields could be aliased/modified by functions called in the loop), and to ensure pages is invariant for the loop condition (i.e. that nothing in the loop can legally modify ps->page_size or ps in a way that affects pages).
